January 18, 2004: Fiction
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a
curator at the Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to
the discovery of a centuries-old secret society.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.)
An old man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that
all will be explained to him in the afterlife.
THE BIG BAD WOLF, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) After joining
the F.B.I., Alex Cross must contend with numerous brazen kidnappings and a
ruthless criminal known as the Wolf.
TRUTH OR DARE, by Jayne Ann Krentz. (Putnam, $24.95.) In Whispering
Springs, Ariz., an interior designer with a supernatural talent and her husband, a
private investigator, are both haunted by their pasts.
TROJAN ODYSSEY, by Clive Cussler. (Putnam, $27.95.) Dirk Pitt and his two
grown children investigate oceanic mysteries off the coast of Nicaragua.
ODD THOMAS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $26.95.) A short-order cook who can
communicate with the dead receives a portent of impending catastrophe.
THE DARK TOWER: Volumes 1-5, by Stephen King. (Viking and Donald M.
Grant/Scribner, various prices.) The tale of an enigmatic gunslinger, Roland
Deschain, and his quest for the nexus of all space and time.
BLEACHERS, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A former star quarterback
returns to his Southern hometown after he learns that his high school coach, a
local legend, has a terminal illness.
THE LADY AND THE UNICORN, by Tracy Chevalier. (Dutton, $23.95.) The
fictional story behind the creation of a famous late-15th-century tapestry series.
POMPEII, by Robert Harris. (Random House, $24.95.) In A.D. 79, a young Roman
engineer whose predecessor has disappeared tries to repair the great aqueduct
near the Bay of Naples and Mount Vesuvius.
THE MURDER ROOM, by P. D. James. (Knopf, $25.95.) Cmdr. Adam Dalgliesh is
busy solving murders and falling in love with a Cambridge lecturer.
BLOW FLY, by Patricia Cornwell. (Putnam, $26.95.) No longer the chief medical
examiner of Virginia, Kay Scarpetta tries to unravel a conspiracy involving the
Wolfman, a killer she helped put away years earlier.
SUNNY CHANDLER'S RETURN, by Sandra Brown. (Bantam, $19.95.) A New
Orleans woman goes back to her small Southern hometown for a friend's wedding.
January 18, 2004
Non-Fiction
LIES (AND THE LYING LIARS WHO TELL THEM), by Al Franken. (Dutton,
$24.95.) A satirical critique of the rhetoric of right-wing pundits and politicians.
DUDE, WHERE'S MY COUNTRY? by Michael Moore. (Warner, $24.95.) The
author of "Stupid White Men" calls for "regime change" in Washington.
FLYBOYS, by James Bradley. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) An account of eight
American airmen who were shot down and captured by the Japanese in World
War II.
WHO'S LOOKING OUT FOR YOU? by Bill O'Reilly. (Broadway, $24.95.) The host
of "The O'Reilly Factor" attacks those individuals and institutions that he believes
have let down the American people.
BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Walter Isaacson. (Simon & Schuster, $30.) A
biography of the scientist, inventor, writer and Revolutionary statesman.
BROKEN MUSIC, by Sting. (Dial, $26.) From life in Newcastle to life with the
Police: a memoir by the rock musician and singer.
A SHORT HISTORY OF NEARLY EVERYTHING, by Bill Bryson. (Broadway,
$27.50.) From the Big Bang to the 21st century: a guided tour of the sciences and
what they tell us about the physical world.
THE ENEMY WITHIN, by Michael Savage. (WND Books, $27.99.) The syndicated
radio talk show host sets out to rebuff "the liberal assault on our schools, faith and
military."
HAD ENOUGH? by James Carville with Jeff Nussbaum. (Simon & Schuster, $23.)
The former adviser to Bill Clinton laces into Republicans and tries to inspire
Democrats.
A ROYAL DUTY, by Paul Burrell. (Putnam, $25.95.) A memoir by the man who
served as butler to Diana, Princess of Wales.
AMERICA 24/7, created by Rick Smolan and David Elliot Cohen. (DK Publishing,
$50.) A collection of photographs that depict one week (May 12-18, 2003) in the
life of the United States.
FRANKLIN AND WINSTON, by Jon Meacham. (Random House, $29.95.) An
account of the friendship between Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill, by
the managing editor of Newsweek.
THE FUNNY THING IS . . . , by Ellen DeGeneres. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A
collection of humor pieces by the stand-up comic and talk show host.
A NATIONAL PARTY NO MORE, by Zell Miller. (Stroud & Hall, $26.) The senior
